title.title: Couple's wedded bliss starts down the aisle Underground

texts: When couples are planning their weddings they usually want a special mode of transport - a vintage car or a horse and carriage - Eliot Maunder and Emily Drabek were no exception - they wanted to travel by Tube!
The new wide aisle gates at the station meant that their guests and the other passengers were able to get through independently and onto the train very quickly.
{"template":"bulletlist","items":["Pictures available on request from the Press Office"]}

After going down the aisle and getting married at Marylebone Register Office Latin teacher Eliot, 28, and PhD student Emily, 25, went through the wide aisle gates at Baker Street Underground station with their wedding party of 30 guests and travelled to Charing Cross for their celebratory meal.

Eliot, of The Cut, Southwark, London, said: 'We wanted to travel on the Underground because it is so quick and easy. I travel on the Tube every day to get to work and it is the best way to get around the capital.
'There are always staff around if you need them - and on this special day we did - they guided us to the front of the train and we had a whole carriage to ourselves for all the wedding guests.'
Emily, from Eldertree Gardens, Exeter, Devon, said: 'When you live in Devon you really do appreciate the public transport in London, particularly the Tube.'
Howard Collins, London Underground's Chief Operating Officer said: 'We want to help all our customers and we are delighted that we could speed this young couple on their way to their wedding meal.
'The new wide aisle gates at the station meant that their guests and the other passengers were able to get through independently and onto the train very quickly.'

In order to help wheelchair and guide dog users, parents with buggies and passengers with luggage a further batch of wide aisle gates have been installed making a total of 348 gates at London Underground stations.

Now 180 London Tube stations - two thirds of the entire London Underground network - have these gates installed, giving passengers more independence and quicker journeys.

It means that customers don't have to ask staff to unlock a gate for them. In turn staff have more time to help customers in a variety of other ways:  at ticket machines, by directing them to the correct platforms, or by guiding visually impaired customers.
